frameDefinitions: Because it no longer functions adequately under the given circumstances, an Agent (or non-Agentive Cause) undertakes steps to change the structural makeup of a complex Entity with interdependent parts, for instance an institution or a system of laws.
Temporary or permanent Styles and Configurations of Hair, as well as its inherent Nature.
Some individual or group ceases to be able to sustain an Endeavor (a long-term activity involving economic interaction with the public, often a business venture).
An Agent has committed a Wrong in the past and is making Amends for it.
The words in this frame describe the process of making amends for some (wrongful) action (the Injury) committed by the Wrongdoer.
An Executive_authority exchanges one penalty, the Original_punishment, for another less severe one, the New_punishment.
frameExamples: They want to <t>reform</t> the law on Sunday trading.
On either side her head gleamed coiled <t>braids</t> of dark-gold hair , almost pale copper in the subdued light of the room .
He <t>atoned</t> for his sin with good works.
On December 15, 1971, Governor Winfield Dunn conditionally <t>commuted</t> his sentence to twenty years.
listRoleDefinitions: The sentient entity that effects a change in the <fen>Entity</fen>.

This role denotes a complex, abstract, human-created entity with interdependent parts which has either deteriorated or is no longer adequate for its purpose given a change in circumstances and which the <fen>Agent</fen> therefore wants to modify.
This role is for non-human causes, such as a processes or institutions, responsible for reform.
The time at which the change of the <fen>Entity</fen> is caused.
The place where the reformation occurs.
This role is the hair itself
This role is the Possessor of the body part.
Temporary Configurations of hair (eg braid, bun, ponytail).   Something done to the hair merely by movement.
A property of the hair (eg curly, fine, brown).  This acts much like 'Descriptor' in the Observable_bodyparts Frame.  Colors, styles, natural properties are described by this frame element.
The <fen>Endeavor</fen> is rendered unable to continue its regular operations.
The <fen>Time</fen> of the failure.
The <fen>Place</fen> of the failing <fen>Endeavor</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> has committed a <fen>Wrong</fen> and is making <fen>Amends</fen>.
<fen>Wrong</fen> identifies the act committed by the <fen>Agent</fen> for which <fen>Amends</fen> are made.
<fen>Amends</fen> marks expressions that indicate what the <fen>Agent</fen> does to compensate for the <fen>Wrong</fen> that was committed.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> atones for the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> expiates the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
The <fen>Injured_party</fen> was affected by some previous wrongful act of the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> and who should benefit from the reparations.
The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action that  the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> committed against the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.  Although conceptually present, this role need not always be realized.
The <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends to the <fen>Injured_party</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Benefiting_action</fen> is performed by the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> to make amends.
<fen>Gift</fen> identifies the entity that the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> gives to the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when amends are made.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends.
The constitutionally specified authority who has the power to commute punishments.
The punishment the <fen>Offender</fen> was originally sentenced to.
The time at which the <fen>Original_punishment</fen>  is commuted.
The location where the <fen>Executive_authority</fen> commutes the <fen>Original_punishment</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Particular attention will be devoted to recent proposals to reform <fex>UK competition policy</fex>.
Thus , <fex>radical reform</fex> restructures rape offences in ways that it is hoped will facilitate the prosecution process without jeopardising the interests of the accused .
The House of Representatives, on a bipartisan basis, sought to reform the program <fex>this year</fex>.
Her <fex><t>tresses</t></fex> were golden.
<fex>Michael's</fex> hair is long.
I pulled Michael's  <fex>ponytail</fex>.
<fex>His small business</fex> failed.
Her campaign failed <fex>in 2008</fex> but found much more support in 2012.
The hot dog stand <fex>on 4th avenue</fex> flopped.
<fex>Syria</fex> has atoned for its support of Iraq.
Smithers is atoning <fex>for his misspent youth</fex>.
He atoned for his sin <fex>with good works</fex>.
You can never make amends <fex>to Susan</fex> for standing her up.
Wyelander sought reparations <fex>for the brutal murder of his nephew</fex>.
How  can <fex>I</fex> make it up to you?
Between friends, amends can be made <fex>by apologizing</fex>.
He made it up to her <fex>with a bouquet of flowers</fex>.
He made amends to her <fex>that very afternoon</fex>.
Restitution was given <fex>in Milan</fex> with the Treaty of Abiselle.
Hearst was sentenced to seven years in prison. 1979, <fex>President Jimmy Carter</fex> commuted Hearst's prison sentence after she served nearly two years.
I had learned after all of this period of time has passed the court was about to let (Bush) pay a sum of money and commute <fex>her sentence</fex> to time served.
Israel <fex>yesterday</fex> commuted the lengthy prison terms of seven Jews convicted of murdering or plotting to kill Arabs.
